For Release Tues PMs, Dec 26 and Thereafter
Academy Award Race Will Feature More Modest Movies
DOC.TEXT: The entries for the 62nd Academy Awards have all made their appearances, and the race shapes up as a contest between the little people and the giants. Critics' awards have already appeared, and although they tend to be more esoteric than the Oscars, the choices indicate a trend toward more modest films. Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing'' was named best picture by the Los Angeles critics, edging out ``Drugstore Cowboy.'' The New York Film Critics Circle chose ``My Left Foot,'' and the National Board of Review selected ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Observers believe that Academy voters will nominate many of the independent and minor-budget films and pay little heed to the multimillion-dollar grossers of 1989, such as ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' ``Look Who's Talking'' and ``Ghostbusters II.'' Victory for the independents would mirror the 1985 awards, when two low-budget films won acting honors: Geraldine Page in ``The Trip to Bountiful'' and William Hurt in ``Kiss of the Spider Woman.'' Here's how the Oscar race appears to this onlooker: _ Best Picture. The question is: Will Academy voters remember well-praised films released earlier in the year? If they do, such pictures as ``sex, lies and videotape,'' ``Do the Right Thing,'' ``When Harry Met Sally...'' and ``Field of Dreams'' might be recognized. But the voters have notoriously short memories, and they may select such recent arrivals as ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' ``Glory,'' ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Two imports, ``My Left Foot'' and ``Henry V'' also stand a chance. _ Best actor. Morgan Freeman seems a certain nominee for his role as the devoted chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' rather than his supporting role as a Union soldier in ``Glory.'' Daniel Day-Lewis is a favorite as the cerebral palsy victim in ``My Left Foot.'' However, oldline Academy members may want to reward the veterans: Gregory Peck as the iconoclastic Ambrose Bierce in ``Old Gringo''; Jack Lemmon as the befuddled oldster in ``Dad''; Jack Nicholson as the Joker in ``Batman''; Paul Newman as roistering Earl Long in ``Blaze.'' Then there are the noteworthy newcomers: Tom Cruise, the Vietnam veteran in ``Born on the Fourth of July''; Kenneth Brannagh as the ruler ``Henry V''; Ron Silver as the much-married Holocaust survivor in ``Enemies, A Love Story.'' _ Best actress. The leaders present a marked contrast: Jessica Tandy, the cantankerous widow in ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and Michelle Pfeiffer, the sexpot chanteuse in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' Other favorites are Andie MacDowell, the betrayed wife in ``sex, lies and videotape''; Pauline Collins, the liberated housewife in ``Shirley Valentine''; and Meg Ryan, the career woman looking for love in ``When Harry Met Sally...'' Kathleen Turner could attract votes for her battling wife in ``The War of the Roses,'' as well as Sally Field for her grieving mother in ``Steel Magnolias.'' Other contenders could very well be Jessica Lange, the lawyer defending her father in ``Music Box,'' and perennial nominee Meryl Streep, the romance novelist of ``She-Devil.'' _ Best supporting actor. Denzel Washington and Morgan Freeman could both be contending as the Union soldiers in ``Glory.'' Martin Landau and Alan Alda might compete for their roles in ``Crimes and Misdemeanors.'' Other possibilities include James Earl Jones, ``Field of Dreams''; Danny Aiello, ``Do the Right Thing''; Armin Muehller-Stahl, ``Music Box''; Robert Loggia, ``Triumph of the Spirit''; and the late Ray McAnally, ``My Left Foot.'' _ Best supporting actress. There's a mixed field including Julie Roberts, ``Steel Magnolias''; Laura San Giacomo, ``sex, lies and videotape''; Anjelica Huston and Lena Olin, ``Enemies, A Love Story''; Diane Wiest, ``Parenthood''; Mary Stuart Masteron, ``Immediate Family''; Olympia Dukakis, ``Dad''; and Brenda Fricker, ``My Left Foot.'' _ Best director. This category is usually dictated by the choices for best picture. The leading candidates are neophyte Steven Soderbergh, ``sex, lies and videotape''; Paul Mazursky, ``Enemies, A Love Story''; Oliver Stone, ``Born on the Fourth of July''; Bruce Beresford, ``Driving Miss Daisy''; Costa-Gavras, ``Music Box''; and Jim Sheridan, ``My Left Foot.'' Some of the above will receive the best possible Valentines when the Academy nominations are disclosed on Feb. 14. The winners will be announced from the stage of the Los Angeles Music Center on March 26.
